problem: The saw was running but getting extremely hot in both brush holders, with visible smoke and burning smell. Both brushes were getting scalding hot at around 70-80°C, indicating the armature was burnt out.
failure_reason: Repair was not completed as the armature needed to be ordered and was not in stock, but repair was deemed worthwhile and will be completed later

problem: The hammer drill had power but was not running. The brushes were worn but not badly enough to stop the machine, indicating another electrical issue was preventing operation.
The saw was making a horrible burning sound when stopping, initially suspected to be bearing problems but turned out to be a loose blade causing slippage during braking.
The impact wrench motor was spinning but the anvil wasn't turning due to cold welding between the steel components, causing the mechanism to bind up completely.
Customer reported the motor was burnt out, smoking heavily, and wouldn't cut straight. The actual issue was the blade was installed backwards, causing it to burn the wood instead of cutting.
The cordless miter saw was running and working properly but was stuck at one angle and couldn't be adjusted because the angle adjustment lever was broken.
A nearly new 2024 hammer drill wasn't running at all. The brushes were completely jammed due to being caked with mud, sand, cement dust, and corrosion, with water still present inside the housing.

The forward and reverse change lever was broken - could go forward but couldn't get it on reverse unless you poke it with your finger. One of the little ends on the change lever had snapped off, likely from getting a bang, being put down wrong, falling over, or having something drop on it.

The speed selector switch board was faulty - the light was working but it wasn't letting you select any other speed. The tool was stuck on high speed and couldn't change down through the speeds. The problem was caused by dust getting into the switch mechanism which acts like little bellows, sucking in dust every time the button is pressed and released.
Tool is completely unresponsive - light comes on but motor makes no sound whatsoever and will not run
failure_reason: Switch costs €100 to replace and motor would likely fail soon after on this 10-year-old machine, making repair economically unviable

problem: Bearings failed and housing melted from overheating - bearing melted the plastic housing and everything was stuck together with black residue on the fan
Not hammering and mechanism was jammed up - tiny spring in the hammer mechanism had failed and crushed, causing the piston to disengage and jam the motor
component: hammer mechanism spring and piston ball joint

problem: Drill bit not staying in the chuck - bit would fall out during use
Motor burnt out - brushes melted into the body and commutator segments burnt and shorted out from extensive use
failure_reason: Repair would cost €70-80 but new tool only costs €130, plus armature damage indicates excessive wear making repair uneconomical

problem: Motor burnt out - armature severely worn and rounded, windings burnt, commutator segments dead or shorted
failure_reason: Extensive wear and damage throughout motor components makes repair uneconomical

problem: Switch worn out and losing contact, tool intermittently not running
failure_reason: Switch costs €70 to replace but tool can be bought new for €90-100, making repair uneconomical

problem: Multiple battery packs with water damage, corrosion on contacts, and dead cells - some packs had 2 dead cells while others were fully charged
failure_reason: Dead cells would need replacement and protection circuits are too sensitive, making repairs uneconomical compared to new battery cost

problem: Multiple battery packs with dead cells - typically first two cells dead while others maintained proper voltage around 4 volts
failure_reason: Cell replacement costs nearly half the price of a new battery, making repair uneconomical

problem: Machine was making noise and had issues running, plus the power cord was kinked and improperly installed near where a screw could go through the cable
18 volt impact wrench was making bad noise and had a seized bearing that caused the motor to keep spinning, rubbing against the housing and melting the plastic clamshell cover
Machine was making noise indicating brush issues and had a broken/unlit power cord tip
Tool holder was not holding bits properly due to worn out keyways, plus had perished rubber rings, broken cap, and debris inside requiring complete disassembly and cleaning
Machine had electrical problems and the armature was blown out with visible damage and raised spots causing it to eat away at the brushes
failure_reason: Repair cost of approximately €400 for motor replacement not economical compared to €600 for new equivalent machine

problem: Customer reported the grinder went 'bang' but no actual fault could be identified during testing - machine ran normally
Switch mechanism was dirty and cruded up, affecting operation
Switch mechanism was dirty with grease and dirt buildup around the switch area
Something was binding up inside the tool, steel bush had moved out of position and was not flush
Switch mechanism was dirty and needed cleaning
Spring in tool holder was not holding properly, spring was completely gone and steel ball was not being held in position
Switch mechanism was dirty and cruded up, described as badly cruded
Double charger with one side working and one side completely dead. Shows signs of water damage with rust marks on the board.
failure_reason: Water damage caused one power supply board to fail, replacement boards not available separately

problem: Chuck completely rusted solid and would not open, motor field/stator burnt out with copper windings turned black from normal color, tool had been left in rain causing total rust seizure.
Tool covered in thick black paint that prevented switch from operating properly.
Water damage caused motor windings to turn black, fan melted onto brush holder, motor completely burnt out from overheating.
failure_reason: Motor completely burnt out, not cost effective to repair given low tool price

problem: Trigger not going through speeds properly, switch connector melted and burnt wires due to overload.
Gearbox not dropping into gear properly due to dirt buildup preventing selector from engaging fully, chuck seized from water damage.
No clear problem identified, appeared to be working normally when tested.
Wiring completely melted due to excessive current draw, connectors totally melted through from overuse and overloading the motor.
failure_reason: Too risky to repair due to potential battery damage from short circuit

problem: Motor windings burnt and turned wrong color, brush contacts cooked from excessive heat and overuse.
failure_reason: Motor windings burnt beyond repair, would fail again quickly due to abuse

problem: Power cord damaged, blades completely broken and smashed, depth adjustment jammed with rust, tool clogged with sawdust preventing motor ventilation.
component: power cord, blades, and depth adjustment

problem: Tool holder shattered and fell apart, common fault for fire department use where tools get regularly abused taking cars apart
Gun was jammed and not firing properly, nail stuck in the mechanism
Motor burnt out, not starting, stinking burning smell from motor, very hot
Charger not working, no power output
failure_reason: Not worth repairing due to cost and complexity of diagnosing board-level faults

problem: High pitched whining sound, switch working but no power getting through, motor not running
failure_reason: All components integrated into one piece, replacement cost equals price of new machine

problem: Brushes completely worn out, motor not running properly
Forward/reverse switch broken and buried on both sides, speed selector connector gone, switch problems
failure_reason: Switch assembly too damaged from apparent physical trauma, multiple components failed

problem: Motor brushes completely worn out, burnt through to wire, spring coils damaged
Dead, not starting, plastic housing melted from excessive heat, aluminum housing discolored from heat
failure_reason: Excessive heat damage melted plastic housing and damaged internal components beyond repair

problem: Batteries green with corrosion, contacts corroded, battery acid leaked out destroying cells
failure_reason: Severe corrosion and acid leakage destroyed battery cells beyond repair

problem: Magnesium base broken, guard housing broken off from being dropped
Motor brushes were worn out with nothing left on one brush, causing performance issues
Motor not starting in bump mode but would start on plunge, trigger dirty inside with blocked contacts not always engaging the motor
Burnt and melted brush holders from heavy use and high amp draw over long periods
Tool not rotating - engaging and working but just not spinning, clutch gear had a single broken tooth
Down on power, starts to smoke after running a little while, motor field burnt up and generating too much heat with worn brushes
Motor burnt out, lost magnetism in field due to overheating
failure_reason: Motor completely burnt out and switch also failed, not economical to repair

problem: Switch problem and motor issues
failure_reason: Both motor and switch failed, not economical to repair

problem: Gearbox issue not going fully into speed, trigger problem
failure_reason: Multiple issues including gearbox and trigger, not economical to repair

problem: Motor burnt out and switch failed
Chuck mechanism stuck, chisel getting stuck in the tool holder due to rust and lack of lubrication
The lead cable was cut and damaged with live wire exposed, and the motor was running but the chuck was not turning due to being not properly in gear
Brushed motor would not run initially, motor brushes were overheated, cracked, and stuck in holders causing poor contact
Chuck was getting hot and failing, trigger was starting to fail
Armature was burnt with raised segments and big gaps, gears were also gone, machine sounded extremely gritty with a lot of slop
failure_reason: Repair not economically viable - armature cost €45 while complete grinder can be bought for €60

problem: Power cord had 10-11 cuts and exposed wires, motor brushes were worn, bearing screws had come loose causing noise and movement
No apparent problem found during testing - tool was running and functioning properly
Tool would not run initially, then started running intermittently due to worn motor brushes that were sticking
Gearbox was worn out, anvil had excessive slack, switch was failing
failure_reason: Multiple expensive components needed replacement making repair uneconomical

problem: Tool holder/chuck was not holding bits properly due to failed lifter spring, switch needed cleaning
Bearing had failed causing the tool to barely turn and bind up, with bearing components scattered inside the housing
Machine was making noise and not running properly, with a kinked power cord that was never installed correctly
18 volt 3/4 inch impact wrench was making bad noise and had seized bearing causing motor to rub against housing and melt the plastic
Machine was popping and making noise, plus had a broken power cord with bare wires at the tip
SDS drill was not holding bits properly because the keyways in the tool holder were completely worn out, plus had perished rubber rings and debris inside
Magnetic drill had electrical problems with blown armature that was raised up and eating away the brushes
failure_reason: Repair cost of approximately 400 euros for motor replacement was not economical compared to buying a new equivalent machine for 600 euros

problem: Customer reported the 9 inch grinder went bang, but no fault could be identified during testing
Off square and not cutting straight. The blade was sitting too far back and the base had dropped, causing cuts to be out of square by 2-3 millimeters.
Chuck was stuck and jammed in the down position. The rubber cap was worn through from drilling too close to concrete walls, causing the chuck to stay locked in open position.
Tool was not working due to internal wire fatigue and breakage from constant vibration. Wire broke at the motor pin connection point.
failure_reason: Wire broke at the motor pin with nothing left to reconnect to. Motor replacement would cost 70-80 euro, not worth it for a tool that costs about 150 euro new.

problem: Not cutting straight, blade dropping to one side. Tool holder was very stiff and difficult to engage properly.
failure_reason: Tool holder is part of lifting rod and gearbox assembly costing 120-130 euro to replace, making repair uneconomical.

problem: Intermittent operation - sometimes working, sometimes stopping dead. Switch was not making full contact consistently.
failure_reason: Switch costs 50 euro but the machine can be bought new for about 90 euro online, making repair uneconomical.

problem: Completely dead, no LED light coming on, no response when trigger pulled. Brushless machine with suspected controller failure.
failure_reason: Controller replacement would cost as much as buying a new machine, making repair uneconomical.

problem: Not working despite LED light coming on. Switch had blown MOSFET, brushes were worn, and stator/field was weak causing high current draw.
failure_reason: Multiple issues requiring switch (60 euro) and brushes (7 euro), plus weak motor field likely to cause future failures. Tool heavily used and worn, better to replace.

problem: Trigger switch was jammed all the way in and not functioning properly. Switch had come out of its track/groove, possibly from being knocked or twisted.
Tool was completely dead - would not turn on at all, no LED light working, despite brushes being brand new and all connections appearing good
failure_reason: Repair pending - controller needs to be ordered and replaced

problem: Tool keeps running but eventually stops and won't work again for a long time, maybe a couple days later it might run again
failure_reason: Not cost effective to repair - motor unit replacement would cost 90-100 Euro but tool can be bought for 100-140 Euro

problem: Grinder was running very freely, motor sputtering, and not stopping quickly due to worn brushes with very little material left
Jigsaw was completely jammed and wouldn't move at all due to gearbox being packed solid with sawdust over time
Drill bit was broken and stuck inside the tool holder chuck, couldn't be removed normally
Nail gun was not firing properly and not sinking nails correctly due to loss of nitrogen gas pressure in the system
Tool holder was worn out - bits would go in but just spin inside the holder, and handle was also spinning freely due to broken indexing disc and worn keyways
Trigger was jammed in position and wouldn't move, drill wouldn't operate due to trigger mechanism being stuck with dirt and grit
Drill bit was stuck in the chuck and the chuck mechanism wasn't working, chuck was jammed on so tight it couldn't be removed normally
One of the screws in the nail guide had broken off, and during service found the reed valve assembly was loose and nail guide was cracked
Making a whirring sound during operation, bearing starting to go dry and fail
Makes noise but not hammering correctly, something wrong with the piston inside, change lever was damaged from previous forced repair attempt
Switch burnt out with melted wires, not working
Making buzzing noise and going very slow, high pitch squeal, controller failing intermittently
failure_reason: Controller failure not worth fixing - costs nearly same as new machine

problem: Works intermittently, sometimes runs and sometimes doesn't work at all
failure_reason: Electronic problem not worth fixing - motor assembly costs around €300 on a €600 machine

problem: Not working, controller/switch failure, machine has done virtually no work but stopped functioning
failure_reason: Controller assembly costs at least €100 on a €200 machine - too expensive to repair

problem: Mechanical problem with blade holder mechanism, pin had come out causing noise and rattling
Noise from gearbox, bearing failure causing rattling, wrong bearing size fitted from factory
Noisy operation, bearing failure and brush holder corrosion, rubber overmolding deteriorating
The grinder turns on but is not doing anything. Investigation revealed one of the field coils had failed internally with a broken connection.
The anvil broke and there was rough play and noise in the gearbox housing, indicating wear.
The drill is hammering but slipping on drill mode due to a broken or disengaged clutch ring.
failure_reason: Parts need to be ordered - clutch kit not in stock

problem: Chuck is not functioning properly and there is an oil leak. Tool needs a new chuck, sleeve, and cap.
failure_reason: Parts need to be ordered - chuck not in stock

problem: Making grinding or bearing noise during operation. Investigation revealed a failed bearing with the cage broken and balls coming out.
Battery retainers are burnt up and bent, motor is completely worn out and seized, controller has failed, and LED light stopped working.
failure_reason: Too many expensive parts need replacement - motor and controller both failed, not economically viable to repair

problem: Motor is rubbing and not running 100% smooth due to worn bearing and armature rubbing against the field due to worn plastic housing.
Trigger not working - motor runs in bump mode but won't fire in single shot mode due to dust blocking the trigger switch contacts.
The blade holder came off when the pin holding it to the spindle snapped, completely detaching the blade holding mechanism.

The hammer was jammed inside and not turning. Upon inspection, two fins of the cast aluminum fan had broken off - one broke and took out the other, jamming up the motor and preventing it from running.
The drill was working but had no hammer function - not even a tap. The impact bolt was stuck solid, rusted and gummed up with dirt and grit from drilling in dirty conditions.
The sander was doing nothing - completely non-functional. Investigation revealed a blown component on the control board that had exploded apart, along with potential bridge rectifier issues.
failure_reason: Customer contact information not available and repair would require expensive parts for a brand not sold by the shop, making it too risky to order parts without guarantee of payment

problem: The chuck was stuck solid and the ratchet mechanism was not working properly. The chuck could not be opened or closed properly and was making grinding noises.
The drill would work as long as the trigger wasn't pulled all the way, but once pulled to full throttle it would stop completely. This indicated a faulty switch that was failing under full load.

Multiple battery packs with various issues including water damage, corrosion, dead cells, and charging problems. One had 6 volts on two cells while others were at proper voltage, another was completely corroded and water damaged.
failure_reason: Batteries had dead cells, extensive water damage, and corrosion. One newer model had water damage and no replacement case available. Repairing would be unsafe due to overcharging risks and not cost effective.

problem: The sander was not running and making clicking noises as if jammed. The base would not turn and the tool appeared completely seized up. A small nylon brake belt had come off and gotten caught in the impeller fan underneath, jamming the entire mechanism.
Tool not switching on, no power. Also had a stiff tool holder that was jammed with grit and stones, preventing full travel to release the chisel.
Makes clicking sounds, motor turns freely but won't run properly. Likely controller, switch, or Hall effect sensor failure.
failure_reason: Motor unit costs over £220 and the complete tool can be bought new for €270, making repair uneconomical

problem: Radio would not power on with either battery or mains power. Power cord was broken with live and neutral wires separated.
Motor runs but spindle/anvil not turning. Steel balls in the hammer mechanism were jammed due to debris and grit in the tracks, and one steel ball was cracked/damaged.
SDS Plus tool holder keyways completely worn away, allowing bits to move around inside and fall out. Power cord also needed replacement. Missing steel balls from tool holder mechanism.
No power, motor would not run. One wire was broken at the connection point.
Compressor would not power on. Switch contacts were stuck together due to dust and dirt accumulation, preventing proper operation.
The tool holder is damaged and locked in the open position. Blade will go in but it's not staying because the spring mechanism that should lock the blade in place has failed.
The switch has failed completely - no click when pressed and the saw won't turn on. Also has damaged wiring with live cable showing.
23 gauge headless pinner no longer sinking nails flush - nails are firing but sticking proud of the timber. The firing pin has actually broken, not just worn.
Bearing has completely failed and the field has come loose, causing rubbing. Machine sounds very bad and steel balls from bearing are floating around inside.
Old half-inch electric drill is tripping the breaker when switched on due to internal wiring shorting to the metal body. After testing, discovered the armature is shorted out.
failure_reason: Armature is shorted out and no replacement parts are available for this old machine

problem: 50L dust extractor not working at all - no power and indicator light not coming on when switched on.
Saw not running properly, brush holder melted, brushes are burnt and of very poor quality construction.
Tool was running rough with a squealing sound at the end, something was squeaking when turning. Fan had shifted and was rubbing against the housing causing noise and potential overheating.
Tool was completely dead, not responding at all, no LED light coming on when battery inserted. Controller appeared to be faulty.
failure_reason: Repair not economically viable - controller costs 90-100 euros but complete tool only costs 150-160 euros to buy new

problem: Motor was making grinding noise indicating bearing failure. Field winding tip was broken with windings pulled out and catching on armature. Tackle ring on armature was coming loose.
Motor runs but not driving screws properly. Screws were sitting loose and not being driven in.
Motor making bad sounds, armature had a blown segment that was completely missing. Tool wouldn't start when stopped on the dead segment but would start when blade was moved to next segment.
Motor sounding rough with grinding noise from bearings. Multiple bearings were worn out and making noise during operation.
Tool had no plug and very short, hardened power cord that was impractical to use
Tool was not running, brushes had been removed and there was a smooth spot on the armature where the brushes had rubbed against the commutator
Tool had vibration and grinding noise from bearings, plus very short power cord
Tool had burnt out armature with darker segments that were blown
failure_reason: Armature replacement would cost more than buying a new grinder, making repair economically unviable

problem: Tool was totally burnt out with blown segments, raised segments acting like a file, burnt windings coming out, and broken spicer bars
failure_reason: Armature was completely destroyed and replacement would cost more than a new grinder

problem: Tool had squealing noise, messed up wiring from previous lead change, burnt brushes, bad armature, failing bearings, and blown field
failure_reason: Multiple major components failed including field, armature, bearings, and brushes making repair too expensive to be worthwhile

problem: Fake Makita SDS hammer drill with counterfeit badges was not switching on at all, doing nothing. Power cord was broken internally.
Customer said it only needed a belt, but upon inspection the drive belt was snapped in half and multiple bearings were completely collapsed and rough, causing the belt failure.

Trimmer was not starting at all, not even a kick. Switch was positioned incorrectly and cocked to one side. Motor head was clogged with grass clippings blocking air vents causing overheating. Shaft connection was loose and pins were missing.
component: trigger switch, air filter, and shaft connection pins

problem: 2006 router was making noise like a jet engine taking off due to worn bearings causing excessive noise and vibration.
Collet cone was completely jammed in the spindle and could not be removed. The cone had worn and rounded over, preventing any bits from being inserted. Customer could not use the tool at all.
No cable, switch was gone, there was something going on with the brushes with a big gap, and one brush was broken with a sharp break
Not working, making a clicking sound which is normally a sign that the brushes have popped out due to wear
Cable had live and neutral wires twisted together in a poor repair job, lead was broken with no neutral connection, brushes were worn but not too bad
Gear problems - gears were chewed up and stripped out, both the gears in the head and the gear on the armature were completely stripped
Gears were stripped out, brushes were completely gone with not much left of them and about to pop, one bearing was starting to fail and becoming very slack
Machine was not running at all despite being switched on and having power to the socket
Machine stopped working completely, was a 20 year old machine from 2004 with original molded plug
Machine was running and hammering but had a service light on indicating brushes were worn out, plus bearing was getting slack
Machine was making a nasty grinding sound and running roughly, turned out to be a counterfeit Bosch with broken connecting rod inside the hammer mechanism mixed with plastic debris in the grease
Machine was running way too fast with no variable speed control and red light was on, hammer action would only work when slowing down but stopped when at full speed
Machine was not getting any power, discovered a broken wire that someone had tried to glue back together
Battery showing no bars, not charging, giving 15.3-15.4 volts which is too low, one bank of cells is dead while others are balanced at 3.65 volts
Broken mounting bracket on the red beam laser
Saw not working with fully charged battery, motor brushes are worn down very far
Old brushed impact wrench doesn't have the same power and has a burning smell
Grinder is noisy and rough running due to a faulty bearing that can be removed by hand
Battery showing only 4.44-4.5 volts instead of 17-20 volts for 18V battery, all cell banks well below 1 volt which is extremely low, jump starting didn't work, circuit board reset didn't work

First battery had physical damage from a fall with damaged casing and terminals, second battery not lighting LED in tool, clicking when trying to charge but not actually charging, showing just over 9 volts and dropping
Battery showing no bars, not registering on drill, getting 12.73V, nickel strip spot weld had failed causing complete disconnection, one cell drained below recoverable voltage while other overcharged
The tool doesn't have the same power as it used to and there's a burning smell coming from it.
The grinder is noisy and stuff, making grinding/grinding noises due to a failed bearing.
Battery only showing 4.4-4.5 volts which is way too low for an 18V battery that should show between 17-20 volts. Individual cell banks were showing 0.92-0.94 volts which is well below viable voltage.
Battery had a fall and looks damaged, the casing looks damaged, there's dirt inside, and having trouble getting it to connect to the top because even the pins are damaged.

Not even lighting LED in the tool, won't charge, makes clicking sounds on charger but doesn't actually charge, showing just over 9 volts and dropping. Individual cell banks showing very low voltage around 1.71-1.75 volts.

No bars on charge, not registering on drill, not even lighting LED, showing 12.7-13.74 volts which is far too low. Corrosion present and complete disconnection where nickel strip spot weld had given way, causing one cell to carry full load while other did nothing.
Tool had two issues - switch problem causing performance issues and chuck/bit holder not retaining bits properly
Owner had to put a screw in to hold the switch on which was not ergonomic and uncomfortable on the finger
Chuck was missing/not working properly and there was hesitation in the trigger response due to dust buildup inside the tool
Bit holder broke off inside the collet, preventing new bits from being inserted properly
Tool was making a horrendous screeching noise during operation
The lights were on but the tool wasn't working - completely non-functional due to worn out motor brushes
The nailer had intermittent operation - sometimes it worked, sometimes it didn't. The tool had been previously opened and had a switch cleaning done before.
The hammer drill was not working at all. Motor was burnt with heat damage to the brushes and armature, and the hammer mechanism needed servicing.
The drill would sometimes go forward when trying to switch to reverse mode instead of reversing direction as intended. The directional control was unreliable.
Motor had expired and needed replacement. Someone had previously replaced the brushes in an attempt to fix it but it didn't work.

9 inch angle grinder that takes two batteries had a switch activator problem. The switch activator was coming out and the owner had to cable tie it closed, which was dangerous. A plastic part was broken off that normally holds the switch down.
Battery pack had defective cells showing less than half a volt while other cells showed 3.84 volts, indicating severe imbalance and cell failure.
Impact driver was working well but had a bit broken off in the chuck that couldn't be removed despite multiple attempts.
Saw was not working properly. Owner had tried replacing brushes and lost one of the caps in the process, but brushes were not the actual problem.
Grinder was noisy and stiff due to a failed bearing that could be removed by hand, indicating complete bearing failure.

Grinder sounded like it had soft start but didn't have that feature, indicating internal problems. The brush holder had overheated and melted, causing the brush caps to close permanently and brushes not making good contact.

9 inch angle grinder has a switch activator problem where the switch activator is coming out, and something broke off the plastic part that holds it down. The owner had used a cable tie to keep it closed which is dangerous.
The SDS machine keeps dropping the bit which is suboptimal. The chuck cover is rough and uneven instead of smooth, which prevents it from holding the ball in and holding the bit in the chuck.

Two Flex volt batteries both only charge to two bars, power 18V machines but give nothing when put in a flex volt tool. Caused by overheat or overload from using one on a faulty flex volt machine and using the other to jump start a smaller battery. Light discoloration visible and connections popped apart under pressure.
About 5 months old demolition hammer has lights on but doesn't work. Initially suspected brushes or lid but brushes had minimal wear and no loose wires. Problem was with the power cable.
Vacuum cleaner not working - put on new fully charged battery and flick switch but get absolutely nothing. Circuit board is fried and switch is burnt out. Only the motor is still good.

4 amp battery showing only 9.6 volts which is very low. Won't work in drill, won't turn on LED, charger won't charge it. Jump start method failed with no spark. One bank of cells gave up completely with basically no voltage.
Performance issues, motor brushes were well worn down and away from the top, burnt or broken terminals, one brush broke during removal
Tool was very greasy from being used in a car repair workshop and had some operational issues
Faulty trigger - the saw was trying to work but could not manage to operate properly
Quick release mechanism lever was not pushing back far enough for blades to fit in properly due to worn blade clamp
Battery was dead with no battery indicator working, one bank of cells was significantly lower voltage at 3.73V compared to others around 4V
The tool was dropping the battery pack - sometimes it would catch if you wiggled it but the connection was unreliable and the battery would fall out during use.
The tool was running continuously and the light was staying on after releasing the trigger. The switch was not disengaging properly, causing the motor to keep running.
The saw was producing smoke when the trigger was pulled and had significant dust buildup. The blade holder mechanism was jammed and difficult to operate, requiring extensive cleaning and lubrication.
Dust coming out of the grinder, overheating issues that melted the brush housing and stopped the brushes from working properly. The brush ring was melted and couldn't be removed easily.
The drill was completely dead with no power when plugged in. There was a slight gap between the armature and brush indicating the brushes were worn out and not making proper contact.
The impact wrench was not working and needed investigation. It was stripped down, cleaned, and reassembled.
The laser was not turning on despite having good battery voltage. The issue was traced to corroded battery contacts and springs in the battery compartment.
The chuck doesn't tighten very well and needs replacement
The drill was not working at all, no response when trigger pulled. Motor brushes were stuck in position and crumbling, with signs of heat damage and melting in the motor

Another drill from an auction that was not working. Motor brushes were not sliding properly, one side was crumbling and stuck. Had to improvise by butchering brushes from the previous repair to make a working set
The yellow battery indicator component was broken on the Makita battery, preventing the battery indicator from functioning properly
The impact driver was not firing or ramping up properly despite having a full battery installed
failure_reason: Did not have the replacement springs needed to complete the repair - springs were broken and would need to be ordered

problem: Very dirty with putrid power cord, drill chuck has rust, handle has a crack on one side, machine not working at all, filter capacitor component ruptured and exploded, metal shards in gearbox from broken thread
Does not work when plugged in and turned on, very dirty, switch was bypassed by previous owner in failed repair attempt, motor brushes corroded and stuck in their sockets unable to slide down
Damaged power cord, some scratches and dirt on the outside
Damaged power cord, very dirty, clutch was previously repaired with brass screw insertion
The power cord needs to be replaced, damaged filter component, motor brushes are quite worn off and the commutator is pretty dirty with both corrosion and carbon dust covering the surface
component: power cord, filter component, motor brushes, commutator

problem: Very dirty with several signs of wear, cable relief is broken, orange power cord is damaged at one end
Battery was completely dead with only 0.022 volts and would not charge on the charger, showing just a red light
Tool was getting flashing lights and not working properly due to dirty battery contacts with black buildup preventing good electrical contact
Tool would not turn on when dial was turned, had black dust everywhere around the tool indicating internal motor problems, and had a major crack/break in the housing case
failure_reason: Major structural damage to housing with full break, plus internal motor issues creating black dust - not economically repairable

problem: Router had a major broken piece in the housing - part of the entire housing/base was broken off
failure_reason: Required replacement part is obsolete and no longer available from manufacturer, and replacement cost would exceed tool value

problem: Spindle lock would not engage in any position, and the shaft was spinning freely without being secured due to missing woodruff key
failure_reason: Could not find the correct size woodruff key at hardware store and manufacturer doesn't sell replacement parts - would need to custom grind one

problem: Battery showed 10 volts but would not charge, had corrosion on the circuit board that was preventing proper charging function
Motor appeared to be completely locked up and would not turn at all when powered on
failure_reason: Multiple internal failures including broken gear tooth, missing snap ring, broken motor fan blade - repair cost would exceed tool value

problem: Battery showed zero volts initially, after jump starting showed 19 volts but still gave four blinking lights error and would not charge due to unbalanced cells
failure_reason: One cell significantly lower voltage than others causing controller to prevent charging/use, would require spot welding replacement cell

problem: Large battery pack would not charge and had two faulty cells reading lower voltage than the other cells in the pack
failure_reason: Two 18650 cells were faulty and would need replacement via spot welding, not confident in repair skills for safe resale

problem: Tool was pretty dirty with grease buildup and dirt accumulation from typical use, requiring deep cleaning of internal components and case
Tool had paint or plaster covering the outside and needed thorough cleaning of external surfaces and some internal cleaning
